lines: This icon represents an experience that one would have in a steady interpersonal relationship. This kind of relationship doesn't exist for you at this time, which is neither good nor bad. Please realize, however, that this condition does
lock you out of part of human experience at this age and station in life.

You and the woman of your dreams are taking a weekend trip with Jill and Mark, a couple you have known for a long time. During the trip you notice Mark becoming irritable, having loud, public discussions about very personal matters and
drinking heavily. You are beginning to think that Mark is an alcoholic.

Your concern is met with hostility. "It's none of your business what goes on between me and my wife," he says, stinking of alcohol. "As far as this stuff is concerned (pointing to the almost empty bottle) I can stop any time I please, so

Your sympathy touches Jill, who has been putting up with Mark's relatively well hidden problem, but it is reaching the point where she is about to completely fall apart. There are times when Mark gets violent, goes on drinking binges and
really acts scary. She doesn't know what to do. What will you advise her?

"That's out of the question," she says. "We've already been to three different marriage counselors. On the days of the appointments, Mark gets his act completely together and the counselor always thinks I'M exaggerating just to get the
attention of my busy husband." The conversation leaves you feeling awkward and uncomfortable.

"But I love him more than anything else in the world," she says. There is no convincing her that she should take better care of herself, because living with a guy like this can be dangerous. The conversation leaves you feeling awkward and
Even though you are feeling concerned, you don't feel right intruding on an area where you may be unwelcome. Not suprisingly, the couple separates two months later. They divorce soon after that.

Your anxiety comes through when speaking with Mark. As a result, he becomes hostile and defensive, telling you to mind your own business. "Every marriage has its problems. I've seen times when you and
have gone at it pretty good yourselves," he says.
Your anxiety comes through when speaking with Jill. As a result, she seeks to reduce your discomfort by minimizing her problems. "It's nothing," she says. "Mark has had a dreadful week."
I can understand how nerve-wracking it can get, listening to another couple fight. It makes everyone around them feel uncomfortable. The arguing doesn't subside. What will you do?
You try to make the best of it, but the weekend leaves you feeling tense and irritable. It's almost as if such emotions are contagious.
It seems like a good idea, until you remember that all four of you drove up in the same car. You are stuck there.

You don't want to stick your nose someplace where it doesn't belong. Even though they are your friends, you don't want to play the role of marriage counselor. Still, you are stuck up there with them for the weekend. What will you do?
#TAKE YOUR LOVER OUT OF THE HOUSE FOR A NICE LONG WALK
#LEAVE TO GO HOME EARLIER THAN YOU HAD PLANNED
Whatever problems there have been between you and your own partner, they seem to disappear. They pale in comparison to what Mark and Jill are going through. The walk is quiet and romantic.
It seems like a good idea, until you remember that all four of you drove up in the same car. You are stuck there.
